commit_message:
Plethora of changes to add functionality and fix basic issues.

1. Added Weave as a working CNI/SDS for inter pod communication.
Weave is far more secure than Canal and gives the user another
option to test and play with.

2. Updated tools, kubernetes, ansible, jinja2 etc. Latest k8s
added and tested.

3. Clean up (-cc) now cleans up docker images much more effectively.

4. Support for Ocata, Pike and Master (Queens)!

5. Support added for customer images in custom repo.

6. Support added for custom tags.

7. Pike and Master Nova work-arounds.

8. Addition of option to run fluent-bit container which now picks
up the logs from containers and forwards to ELK etc.

9. Lots of code and message format consistency.

10. Removal Pike Docker registry work-around - now works with real
images from dockerhub.

11. Cinder V3 API integration (still dev mode).

Change-Id: I35d3cd6a09425a2a0fd5080e9eb4f4e8bb957b5d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-kubernetes refs/changes/26/532626/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
ko.py - Kolla Kubernetes Openstack deployerThis tool exists primarily to: 1. Provide an easy way to run kolla-kubernetes which is a development project to deploy Kolla OpenStack images on a Kubernetes Cluster. 2. Ease development of kolla-kubernetes. 3. Provide an OpenStack environment that is Production Level. 2. Requires just a VM with two NIC's, low congnitive overhead: 'ko.py int1 int2'.5. Options to change the image version (openstack release) and image tag (micro-version) of OpenStack as needed. The user can quickly play with Ocata, or Pike or Master(Queens).8. Verifies its completeness by generating a VM in the OpenStack Cluster.11. Cleans up previous deployment with --cc option 12. Select a different docker registry to the default (kolla) to run with custom images. 13. Select between Canal and Weave CNI's for inter-pod communications. 14. Optionally installs a fluent-bit container for log aggregation to ELK. 15. Option to create a kubernetes minion to add to existing deployment. 16. Option to create a kubernetes cluster only - no OpenStack - but another option to install OpenStack over an existing Kubernetes cluster. 17. Option to not overwrite kolla-kubenetes directory for development of kolla-kubernetes code. 2. Note there are various todo's scattered inline as well. 3. Can be run remotely with: curl https://raw.githubusercontent.com/RichWellum/k8s/master/ko.py \ | python - ens3 ens4 --image_version master -cni weave epilog='E.g.: ko.py eth0 eth1 -iv master -cni weave --logs
') parser.add_argument('-it', '--image_tag', type=str, help='Specify a different Kolla tag version to ' 'the default which is the same as the image_version ' 'by default') parser.add_argument('-kv', '--k8s_version', type=str, default='1.9.1', 'the default(1.9.1) - note 1.8.0 is the minimum ' default='2.4.2.0', 'the default(2.4.2.0)') parser.add_argument('-jv', '--jinja2_version', type=str, default='2.10', 'the default(2.10)') parser.add_argument('-dr', '--docker_repo', type=str, default='kolla', help='Specify a different docker repo from ' 'the default(kolla), for example "rwellum" has ' 'the latest pike images') parser.add_argument('-cni', '--cni', type=str, default='canal', help='Specify a different CNI/SDN to ' 'the default(canal), like "weave"') parser.add_argument('-l', '--logs', action='store_true', help='Install fluent-bit container') 'will proceed without user input.') parser.add_argument('-nn', '--no_network', action='store_true', help='Do not try to create a OpenStack network model, ' 'configure neutron, download and install a test VM') help='Select this to not override git repos ' 'previously downloaded') 'the default(centos), like "ubuntu"') parser.add_argument('-c', '--cleanup', action='store_true', help='YMMV: Cleanup existing Kubernetes cluster ' 'before creating a new one. Because LVM is not ' 'cleaned up, space will be used up. ' '"-cc" is far more reliable but requires a reboot') parser.add_argument('-cc', '--complete_cleanup', action='store_true', help='Cleanup existing Kubernetes cluster ' 'then exit, rebooting host is advised') versions = ["ocata", "2.7.2", "1.9.1", "2.4.2.0", "2.10"] '''Print out lots of information Tool versions, networking, user options and more ''' banner('Kubernetes - Bring up a Kubernetes Cluster') run_shell(args, 'sudo apt autoremove -y && sudo apt autoclean') print('
Linux Host Info: %s' % linux_ver_det()) print(' CNI/SDN: %s' % args.cni) print(' Jinja2 version: %s' % tools_versions(args, 'jinja2').rstrip()) print(' Openstack version: %s' % tools_versions(args, 'kolla')) print(' Image Tag version: %s' % kolla_get_image_tag(args)) print('
Options:') print(' Logging enabled: %s' % args.logs) print(' Dev mode enabled: %s' % args.dev_mode) print(' No Network: %s' % args.no_network) print(' Demo mode: %s' % args.demo) print(' Edit Cloud: %s' % args.edit_cloud) print(' Edit Globals: %s' % args.edit_globals) time.sleep(2) TIMEOUT = 2000 # Give k8s 2000s to come up # Useful for debugging issues when Service fails to start print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Installing environment', K8S_FINAL_PROGRESS) 'libssl-dev python-pip sshpass apt-transport-https') '''Setup NTP''' print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Setup NTP', K8S_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Turn off SELinux', K8S_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Turn off firewall and ISCSID', K8S_FINAL_PROGRESS) 'Create Kubernetes repo and install Kubernetes ', K8S_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Start docker and setup the DNS server with ' 'the service CIDR', K8S_FINAL_PROGRESS) # https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46726216/kubelet-fails-to-get-cgroup-stats-for-docker-and-kubelet-services run_shell( args, 'sudo echo Environment="KUBELET_DOS_ARGS=--runtime-cgroups=/systemd' '/system.slice --kubelet-cgroups=/systemd/system.slice --hostname-' 'override=$(hostname) --fail-swap-on=false" >> /tmp/10-kubeadm.conf') print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Reload the hand-modified service files', K8S_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Enable and start kubelet', K8S_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Fix iptables to enable bridging', K8S_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Deploying Kubernetes with kubeadm (Slow!)', K8S_FINAL_PROGRESS) '--service-cidr=10.3.3.0/24 --ignore-preflight-errors=all ' '--service-cidr=10.3.3.0/24 ' '--ignore-preflight-errors=all')) '--service-cidr=10.3.3.0/24 ' '--ignore-preflight-errors=all') print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Load kubeadm credentials into the system', K8S_FINAL_PROGRESS)def k8s_deploy_cni(args): '''Deploy CNI/SDN to K8s cluster''' if args.cni == 'weave': print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Deploy pod network SDN using Weave CNI', K8S_FINAL_PROGRESS) weave_ver = run_shell(args, "echo $(kubectl version | base64 | tr -d '
')") curl( '-L', 'https://cloud.weave.works/k8s/net?k8s-version=%s' % weave_ver, '-o', '/tmp/weave.yaml') # Don't allow Weave Net to crunch ip's used by k8s name = '/tmp/ipalloc.txt' with open(name, "w") as w: w.write("""\ - name: IPALLOC_RANGE value: 10.0.0.0/16 """) run_shell(args, 'chmod 777 /tmp/ipalloc.txt /tmp/weave.yaml') run_shell(args, "sed -i '/fieldPath: spec.nodeName/ r " "/tmp/ipalloc.txt' /tmp/weave.yaml") run_shell( args, 'kubectl apply -f /tmp/weave.yaml') return # If not weave then canal... # /etc/kubernetes/manifests/kube-controller-manager.yaml # and the kubeadm init command must match print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Deploy pod network SDN using Canal CNI', K8S_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Add API Server', K8S_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Mark master node as schedulable by untainting the node', K8S_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kolla', 'Overide default RBAC settings', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kolla', 'Deploy Helm Tiller pod', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kolla', 'Helm successfully installed', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Kubeadm reset', K8S_CLEANUP_PROGRESS, True) print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Delete /etc files and dirs', K8S_CLEANUP_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Delete /var files and dirs', K8S_CLEANUP_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Delete /tmp', K8S_CLEANUP_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Remove cinder volumes and data', K8S_CLEANUP_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Cleanup docker containers and images', K8S_CLEANUP_PROGRESS) # Clean up docker containers run_shell(args, "sudo docker rm $(sudo docker ps -q -f 'status=exited')") run_shell(args, "sudo docker rmi $(sudo docker images -q -f " "'dangling=true')") run_shell(args, "sudo docker volume rm -f $(sudo docker volume " "ls -qf dangling=true)") # Remove docker images on system run_shell(args, "sudo docker rmi -f $(sudo docker images -a -q)") if args.complete_cleanup: print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Cleanup done. Highly recommend rebooting ' 'your host', print_progress('Kubernetes', 'Cleanup done. Will attempt ' print_progress('Kolla', 'Clone kolla-kubernetes', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) pause_tool_execution('DEV: edit kolla-kubernetes repo now') print_progress('Kolla', 'Install kolla-ansible and kolla-kubernetes', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) run_shell(args, 'sudo -H pip install -U kolla-ansible/ kolla-kubernetes/') print_progress('Kolla', 'Copy default kolla-ansible configuration to /etc', print_progress('Kolla', 'Copy default kolla-ansible configuration to /etc', print_progress('Kolla', 'Copy default kolla-kubernetes configuration to /etc', print_progress('Kolla', 'Setup Loopback LVM for Cinder (Slow!)', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kolla', 'Install Python Openstack Client', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kolla', 'Generate default passwords via SPRNG', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) 'Create a Kubernetes namespace "kolla"', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kolla', 'Label Nodes controller and compute', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) 'and neutron_interface', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kolla', 'Add default config to globals.yml', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kolla', 'Set libvirt type to QEMU', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kolla', 'Generate the default configuration', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) 'Generate secrets and register them with Kubernetes', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kolla', 'Generate and register the Kolla config maps', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) 'Build and register all Helm charts (Slow!)', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) run_shell( args, './kolla-kubernetes/tools/helm_build_all.sh /tmp') print_progress('Kolla', 'Verify number of helm images', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) # Note for local registry add "docker_registry: 127.0.0.1:30401" print_progress('Kolla', 'Create a version 5+ cloud.yaml', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kolla', "Helm Install service chart: \--'%s'--/" % chart, KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kolla', "Helm Install micro service chart: \--'%s'--/" % chart, KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) 'Create a keystone admin account', print_progress('Kolla', 'Allow Ingress by changing neutron rules', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) def kolla_pike_workaround(args): '''An issue in Pike with nova that needs to be fixed I believe this is because we are using the simple cell setup which is really an upgrade scenario. Kolla-Ansible does not do this. https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/user/cells.html#step-by-step-for-common-use-cases The chart jobs are commented out below but that didn't fix it for me. ''' if not re.search('ocata', args.image_version): print_progress('Kolla', 'Fix Nova, various issues, nova scheduler pod ' 'will be restarted', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) # todo: get these jobs to work # chart_list = ['nova-cell0-create-db-job'] # helm_install_micro_service_chart(args, chart_list) # chart_list = ['nova-api-create-simple-cell-job'] # helm_install_micro_service_chart(args, chart_list) run_shell(args, 'kubectl exec -it nova-conductor-0 -n kolla ' 'nova-manage db sync') run_shell(args, 'kubectl exec -it nova-conductor-0 -n kolla ' 'nova-manage cell_v2 discover_hosts') run_shell(args, 'kubectl delete pod nova-scheduler-0 -n kolla') k8s_wait_for_running_negate(args) IMAGE_URL=http://download.cirros-cloud.net/0.4.0/ IMAGE=cirros-0.4.0-x86_64-disk.img if args.no_network: return print_progress('Kolla', 'Create a demo VM in our OpenStack cluster', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) create_demo_vm = ' . ~/keystonerc_admin; openstack server ' \ print(' To create a demo image VM do:') print_progress('Kolla', 'Create floating IP', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kolla', 'Demo VM Info', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kolla', 'To Access Horizon:', KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS) print_progress('Kolla', 'Final Kolla Kubernetes OpenStack ' 'pods for namespace %s:' % name, KOLLA_FINAL_PROGRESS)def k8s_check_nslookup(args): k8s_deploy_cni(args) k8s_check_nslookup(args) '''Set the image tag In most cases the image tag is now the same as the image version. For example, ocata = ocata. But for self-built images, then we need an image tag as that is specified or generated by kolla build tool. So if user has entered an image tag - use it. if args.image_tag: return(args.image_tag) else: return(args.image_version) def kolla_install_logging(args): '''Install log collection Experimental to test out various centralized logging options https://github.com/kubernetes/charts/blob/master/stable/fluent-bit/values.yaml Kafka can be added, but it's only available in a dev image. repository: fluent/fluent-bit-kafka-dev tag: 0.4 Note that both changes to the forwarder and kafka require changes to the helm chart. subject: Pass OSC interface through to barbican plugin
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-26 08:43:24.000000000', 'files': ['barbicanclient/osc_plugin.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-barbicanclient/commit/9f6dcb0617217241ea4260bd421b19dde35160b5', 'message': "Pass OSC interface through to barbican plugin

python-openstackclient uses OS_INTERFACE or --os-interface to select a
catalog endpoint to work with. The barbican CLI uses BARBICAN_INTERFACE
or --interface, which OSC won't pass through. This is a problem because
the it prevents the user from selecting a non-public endpoint when using
barbican via openstackclient rather than as a standalone CLI. This patch
updates the osc plugin to pass through the interface set by OSC to the
barbican client class.

Change-Id: I1e9890c9e87fb77b272f939bf33914df739aa5be
(cherry picked from commit 4afb43ab0115f42b4fadcbf19ecac81815d481e3)
"}]
commit_message:
Pass OSC interface through to barbican plugin

python-openstackclient uses OS_INTERFACE or --os-interface to select a
catalog endpoint to work with. The barbican CLI uses BARBICAN_INTERFACE
or --interface, which OSC won't pass through. This is a problem because
the it prevents the user from selecting a non-public endpoint when using
barbican via openstackclient rather than as a standalone CLI. This patch
updates the osc plugin to pass through the interface set by OSC to the
barbican client class.

Change-Id: I1e9890c9e87fb77b272f939bf33914df739aa5be
(cherry picked from commit 4afb43ab0115f42b4fadcbf19ecac81815d481e3)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-barbicanclient refs/changes/86/538186/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: region_name=instance._region_name, interface=instance.interface)

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I43a4bd6837f2a3e4f6bd4a50c9857e448be13c49

commit_message:
kube-state-metrics for kubernetes version 1.8

This PS is kube-state-metrics for kubernetes version 1.8.
Using kube-state-metrics:v1.2.0 image makes kube-state-
metric pod work properly. Also, gives authority to list
endpoints, persistentvolumes, and horizontalpodautoscalers
by adding them to clusterrole.

commit_message:
fix custom configuration file path

The parameter [] is not None, so when we specified a custom configuration
file(such as '/my/etc/cloudkitty/cloudkitty.conf' not the default
'/etc/cloudkitty/cloudkitty.conf'), it didn't work, the cloudkitty still
load the default configuration file. We need to set the parameter to None.

Change-Id: Id1ac4378cff618d418b9fb92c4b21e6f322d9250
Closes-Bug: #1735966

commit_message:
fix jobs to create a secret can work on upgrade

This PS fixes the jobs falling into a crash loop state
when upgrading charts.

'kubectl create' command cannot overwrite if a secret already
exists. But 'kubectl apply' command can do it.

Change-Id: Idd6eea06892a30e36e51a9b1130fd7cd84ff65cf

commit_message:
Improve user experience by simplifying the guides

We should as much as possible simplify the deploy guide, and
if possible, reduce the amount of duplicate documentation.

I think this spec shows a few areas of improvements we could set
in place to streamline the user experience.

Change-Id: If884c7a56f9bc97a89973ae98840b5783fb88b88
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-specs refs/changes/50/531850/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Documentation improvements ########################## :date: 2018-01-08 22:00 :tags: docs, user stories, walkthrough Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+spec/example People are often confused when they deploy with openstack-ansible, because they only partially read the documentation, or landed on the wrong documentation. Our deployment guide is already close to what I call a wizard/ walkthrough, but some parts are easily missed by the deployers. On top of that, some very nice advanced documentation are often skipped, or aren't promoted to their right value. Problem description =================== When people land on our deployment guide, which is probably the first link they access, whether they come from the OpenStack deployment guides https://docs.openstack.org/pike/deploy/ or from our main developer page https://docs.openstack.org/openstack-ansible/latest/ , they are facing the following issues: * The landing page is overwhelming, as its a series of link. What do you click? * The first links clicked (example: https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/openstack-ansible/pike/overview.html#) is just more clicks towards content, and doesn't provide any useful information (the structure is already displayed on the left side of the page). * Anyone wanting to quickly deploy an openstack-ansible cloud has no way to know we have an AIO toolkit that could help. * Anyone wanting to deploy a production cluster with Netapp for example will most likely not find the appropriate documentation while reading the deploy guide: It's easy to miss the importance of configuration on https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/openstack-ansible/latest/configure.html#advanced-service-configuration * The AIO is listed in the "contributor" guides, where it could be available on any deployment part. * There is an hard to find "advanced configuration" section, hidden inside the operations guide. It should probably be an appendix of the deploy guide. * We have many overlaps of documentation doing about the same thing, we should clean things up (for example the advanced configurations in deploy + operations, the inventory in operations + contributors + reference) * There are too many appendices in the deploy guide. Some deserve their own section. According to the spec http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/docs-specs/specs/pike/os-manuals-migration.html, "end-user content such as concept guides, advice, tutorials, step-by-step instructions for using the CLI to perform specific tasks, etc." I think we could technically move scenarios there, as they are step-by-step instructions using shell scripts to perform some specific deploys. * The role maturity is hard to find. If I were a new deployer, I'd like to know what I could do with OpenStack-Ansible, and the role maturity matrix would tremendously help. Sadly I'd never see it in my first read of the documentation. * The upgrade guide is our user guide. Why not considering upgrades as a specific kind of operation? In my opinion, it should be part of the operations guide, as a major chapter in the operations, in the same way as minor updates, or scaling the environment. * We don't motivate people to contribute back directly from the deploy guide. The last step after verifying that the system works should be how to extend and contribute to OpenStack-Ansible. Proposed change =============== Have some kind of notice at the beginning of the deploy guide, pointing to our user stories (but advising to read the deploy guide first). The first user story would be the AIO, with the quickstart AIO content, for those who want devstack-like easiness, developers, or for those who want to prototype. Add more user stories into the user guide, for ceph (test, prod and ceph-ansible integration), for l3 routed scenarios (tests and prod), for offline installs. Move advanced topics like inventory, container networking, custom layouts and security principles into a new "reference" section of the documentation. This section should probably hold the links to roles' documentations, and should also be linked from the deploy guide where appropriate. Highlight the importance, in the deploy guide, of our advanced topics (reference). It's important for new deployers to know where to find documentation on how to do X that's not part of a user guide. At the end of the deploy guide, continue the deploy story by pointing to our operations and contributions guide. That could be added into a next steps section. For improving the reading experience, ensure that each page has a proper structure: - Only content should appear in the content part of the page - The chapters should only be in the upper-left section of the page ToC, and pointing to this guide chapters, not the whole documentation items (avoiding something like https://docs.openstack.org/openstack-ansible/latest/user/index.html) - The page headers should only be in the lower-left section of the page ToC. Alternatives ------------ Not changing the docs, or partially implementing those changes. Playbook/Role impact -------------------- None Upgrade impact -------------- None Security impact --------------- None Performance impact ------------------ None End user impact --------------- None Deployer impact --------------- New deployers should be less overwhelmed by Openstack-Ansible Developer impact ---------------- None Dependencies ------------ None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: jean-philippe-evrard Other contributors: * TODO Work items ---------- Each paragraph of the proposed change can be considered as a work item. Testing ======= Nothing new. Documentation impact ==================== This is a docs only change, so this whole change has a documentation impact. However, because we don't change the structure of the docs themselves, it should not be very difficult to implement. References ========== This improvements only happen to improve our readability, and to follow what's generally expected to find in each of the documentations:

commit_message:
simplify shrinking

When a donor/acceptor pair are found for shrinking, don't update their
timestamps and namespaces in the root db immediately but wait for the
shrinking shard to send updates back to root. That way the root shard
range table only changes once the donor has replicated to the
acceptor.

Before, the acceptor shard range namespace was expanded in the root
shard range db *before* the donor objects had cleaved to it, so there
was a window of time when a listing would have 'lost' the donor
objects.

Also, send a single PUT request to donor to both update its shard
ranges and set its Scan-Done sysmeta. This requires the container
server accepting sysmeta updates with shard range updates.

Change-Id: I3fddaf1f3dd24abfb4f3011d792580719ffc27cd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/72/536772/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # TODO: yuk, need to send state to root to avoid resetting # it to CREATED when a donor has cleaved an expanded # namespace and *new timestamp* to this shard, but should # we be persisting the actual state rather than hard code # it? own_shard_range.state = ShardRange.ACTIVE # Update the acceptor shard container with its expanded shard # range but leave its timestamp unchanged; this means that the # acceptor will accept any object updates that the donor might # redirect to it while the donor is in sharding state # (equivalent to when a new shard has been found but not yet # cleaved). # Note that the acceptor namespace is not yet changed in the # root; and any updates from the acceptor to root will not # change the acceptor namespace because its created_at # timestamp has not advanced. # TODO: OR we could skip this step and wait for the act of # cleaving from the donor to update the acceptor lower range - # between now and that happening, updates redirected to the # shrinking range would either land there and become misplaced # or get redirected from the donor to the acceptor and become # misplaced until cleaving happens. # Now send a copy of the expanded acceptor, with an updated # timestamp, to the donor. The donor will pass this newer # timestamp to the acceptor when cleaving, so that subsequent # updates from the acceptor will update the root to have the # expended acceptor namespace. # Set Scan-Done so that the donor will not scan itself and will # TODO: when shrinking, include deleted own (donor) shard range # in the replicated db so that when acceptor next updates root # it will atomically update its namespace and delete the donor # Do not do the same when sharding a shard because we're not # ready to handover donor namespace until all shards are # cleaved.
deleted_lines: updated_shard_ranges = [] # update the acceptor shard container with its expanded shard range # but leave its timestamp unchanged # TODO: update the shard container lower bound now so that it # starts to accept updates for its expanded range...OR we could # have the act of cleaving from the donor update the acceptor lower # range - between now and that happening, where do updates for the # retired range get directed? # give the acceptor a fresh timestamp so that the only shard range # updates accepted at the root will be for the expanded acceptor # shard range once it receives its new timestamp via replication # from the retiring shard container # TODO: maybe we should use a separate (expiring?) timestamp - # there is a risk here that if the async shrinking never happens # then the acceptor shard can never update itself or even delete # itself # update acceptor usage in root container table to best estimate # for purposes of summing root container shard usages # Give the donor a fresh timestamp. This prevents the root merging # usage updates from any un-shrunk instances of the shard. Also # set Scan-Done so that the donor will not scan itself and will donor = donor.copy(timestamp=Timestamp.now()) # TODO: not sure we really want to delete the donor yet but need # some way to ensure it is passed over in future shrink cycles; # some audit process should delete the shard once it has emptied donor.state = ShardRange.SHRUNK updated_shard_ranges.append(donor) updated_shard_ranges.append(acceptor) if updated_shard_ranges: # merge all changed shard ranges into root shard_ranges table broker.merge_shard_ranges( [dict(sr) for sr in updated_shard_ranges]) # TODO: almagamate this replicate with one after find_shard_ranges # if any mods were made to broker self.cpool.spawn( self._replicate_object, part, broker.db_file, node['id']) any(self.cpool) self.logger.debug('shrink done, modified %s' % updated_shard_ranges)

The _kibana.sh.tpl template ended up in the elasticsearch chart
templates folder. This removes it

commit_message:
Add disable floating ip parameter

Fix behaviour of --floating-ip-enabled and add --floating-ip-disabled.
Removed default setting of floating_ip_enabled API call parameter from
the clients (now the API default is used if it's not explicitly set in
the client arguments).

Change-Id: I9e01addaab17a0d37bb2fed10b4672d421bc1e09
Closes-Bug: #1639119

commit_message:
Prometheus: Use volume claims to support RWO storage class

This PS uses volumeClaimTemplates to provide multiple
pvcs and pvs to prometheus statefulset's multiple pods.
This gives ability to provide read-write-many access
backend by a read-write-once storage class.

Change-Id: I53d1b866c0c87f0833941b612d3acfbe5742744f

commit_message:
Switch (back) ubuntu DIB to use AFS mirror in rackspace

In I4bda502f31087bc125bd452a9075e3caaa031c7d we mistakenly removed
this syntax. Add it back, as it protects our images downloading new
packages before AFS mirrors have had a chance to sync them.

Change-Id: Ie6574777049e456f9deb57b3b6fedddb27b9a1ff
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

Add code hosting URL

This adds the URL for the source, so that it is available to
contributors (both via the CONTRIBUTING.rst file and the
'Contributing' documentation page).

commit_message:
Tune prometheus default intervals and block durations

This increases the default scrape and evaluation intervals to match
those of the prometheus service upstream with the aim to reduce
prometheus's resource consumption. It also adds configuration
parameters for the min and max block durations that series can
span

Change-Id: I7f9352413a273fbf680b892ba26e30cf27bae232
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm-infra refs/changes/83/536383/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: scrape_interval: 60s evaluation_interval: 60s

subject: Remove unit tests for ML2 Mechanism driver
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-10 09:22:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl/commit/655e066f8fbf8157399da400529d33cb394b8d9a', 'message': "Remove unit tests for ML2 Mechanism driver

The test cases importing `neutron.tests.unit.plugins.ml2.test_plugin` and
creating classes with noop operation [1] follow a faulted pattern. The
reasons are twofold:

1. If the mechanism driver is not loaded correctly [2], the tests then
don't test the mechanism driver but still succeed and therefore there is
no indication that there is something wrong with the code.

2. It gives a false sense of reassurance. If the code of those tests is
analyzed it's possible to see that the code itself is mostly centered
around testing the REST endpoint of neutron than actually testing that
the mechanism succeeds on the operation it was supposed to test. As a
result of this, there is marginally added value on having those tests.
To be clear, the hooks for the respective operations are called on the
mechanism driver, but the result of the operation is not asserted.

For more reference please refer to the mailing list conversations that
discuss this issue:

1. https://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/neutron-dev/2017-December/001499.html
2. http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-December/125466.html

[1]: http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=class%20.*\(.*TestMl2
[2]: something that was happening in networking-odl and addressed by

commit_message:
Remove unit tests for ML2 Mechanism driver

The test cases importing `neutron.tests.unit.plugins.ml2.test_plugin` and
creating classes with noop operation [1] follow a faulted pattern. The
reasons are twofold:

1. If the mechanism driver is not loaded correctly [2], the tests then
don't test the mechanism driver but still succeed and therefore there is
no indication that there is something wrong with the code.

2. It gives a false sense of reassurance. If the code of those tests is
analyzed it's possible to see that the code itself is mostly centered
around testing the REST endpoint of neutron than actually testing that
the mechanism succeeds on the operation it was supposed to test. As a
result of this, there is marginally added value on having those tests.
To be clear, the hooks for the respective operations are called on the
mechanism driver, but the result of the operation is not asserted.

For more reference please refer to the mailing list conversations that
discuss this issue:

1. https://lists.opendaylight.org/pipermail/neutron-dev/2017-December/001499.html
2. http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-December/125466.html

[1]: http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=class%20.*\(.*TestMl2
[2]: something that was happening in networking-odl and addressed by
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/523934

Change-Id: I242a7f69d62f6e3365164cf8d104a5cf0a8499b0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl refs/changes/67/532467/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Pause ubuntu-xenial image uploads

Our Ubuntu Xenial package mirrors have fallen behind again, so newly
built ubuntu-xenial images boot a system unable to install packages
due to dependency version conflicts. Pause these for now so we can
roll back to the previous images while we work on fixing our mirror
updates.

Change-Id: I73124c6543554bb4456f36c0822ba2b8d00b523f

commit_message:
WIP; whip it real good

Change-Id: I734d80d73652963b516a4e20efaaaa4889be90b5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/93/440593/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Example Spec - The title of your blueprint ========================================== `bp example <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/example>`_ We are adding a new authentication mechanism. Problem Description =================== Currently there isn't a good way to provide authentication credentials to a script or third-part application. You can give them you password, but that means that it has access to anything you have access to. You can authenticate manually and use the obtained token, but that means that it will eventually expire. Rquirements: * Allow for the creation of many keys (ideally users will create a new API key for each cron job, script, etc.) * Force API keys to only be a subset of the roles available to the user * API keys should be scoped, but there is something to be said about admin jobs that cross domain/project boundaries. There is some debate to be had here. * API keys are to be created once and never stored in keystone. This means that a user will not be able to go in and ask for them again. If they lose a key they will have to create a new one. * API keys cannot be used to create a token with a larger scope or lifetime. Proposed Change =============== * Create a new CRUD API for dealing with API key * Allow a user to pass the API to keystone using the exiting X-Auth-Token header (or maybe a new one; now sure why we don't use Authorization) in the following format: key_id:key. Since the string is largely opaque (or should be) the user won't have to know the format. To them it's just a string. * To validate we will use the key_id to find the API key and hash the key using passlib to verify it. Once verified we will create the context used for policy by grabbing the scope and roles assigned to that API key. * We *may* provide a mechanism to force expiration, but there was some debate on this at the PTG. * The key itself can be just 128 or 256 random bytes. Alternatives ------------ [I'm sure there are some] Security Impact --------------- * A compromise will be limited to the authorization of the API key, but will last until the compromise is noticed. * Passwords are no longer needed in configuration files. [I'm sure there is more here] Notifications Impact -------------------- No Other End User Impact --------------------- The spec talks about the end user impact above. Performance Impact ------------------ Probably no impact. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- * Possibly some new configuration * New APIs that may need policy consideration Developer Impact ---------------- No Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: <launchpad-id or None> Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Work Items ---------- 1. Implement 2. Profit Dependencies ============ None Documentation Impact ==================== None - other than needing some References ========== I'm to lazy to find reference to the PTG discussions right now. Maybe later?

commit_message:
Define a richer policy by default

Follow nova's lead to determine what roles we should provide by
default.

bp richer-policy

Change-Id: Ife37772cbfa00581d84860e9fca022de100e585b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/54/428454/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================== Richer Policy by Default ======================== `bp richer-policy<https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/richer-policy>`_ Operators have complained about the lack of granularity in default policy files for several releases. We should propose a standard set of default roles that we can start moving towards. Operators can continue to override policy using their ``policy.json`` files, but we should be able to provide reasonable RBAC defaults out of the box. Problem Description =================== The default policy settings provided by keystone today were developed a long time ago for a very limited set of use cases. As OpenStack has grown into more and more complex deployments, it has also outgrown its dated RBAC model. The lack of granularity in our default policy forces operators to craft their own policy by hand, which is not only hard to do, but also causes inconsistencies in interoperability across deployments. With the ability to define policy defaults in code, we should be able to move our defaults to something more reasonable and granular. Proposed Change =============== We should provide the following roles by default in our policy: * Project observer (PO): has the ability to authenticate and validate tokens scoped to a specific project. Users with this role then have the ability to use that token to list resources owned by other projects. * Project member (PM): has the ability to authenticate and validate tokens scoped to a specific project. Users with this role then have the ability to use that token to create, read, update, or delete resources owned by other projects. * Domain observer (DO): has the ability to view projects, groups, users, and roles within that domain. They are not allowed to create of modify anything within the domain. * Domain member (DM): has all the ability of the Domain observer, but they can create projects, groups, users, and roles within that domain. They can also manage role assignments between projects users and groups within the domain. * Operator observer (OO): has the ability to list services, endpoints and regions. Users with this role cannot make any changes to the service catalog. * Operator member (OM): has all the abilities of the Operator observer in addition to being able to manage services, endpoints, and regions. * Keystone Administrator (KA): has the ability to manage anything within the identity system. Alternatives ------------ None, keep things the way they are. Security Impact --------------- This would effectively improve security by coupling operations according to how destructive they are in nature. This also makes it easier for new deployments to achieve the principal of least operation by providing roles that only give users what they need and nothing more. Notifications Impact -------------------- None. Other End User Impact --------------------- They would be provided with a more consistent experience across services that implement the same roles for similar API operations. Performance Impact ------------------ For projects that have policy in code, they might notice a slightly higher memory footprint as a result of registering seven roles/rule combination instead of just two (``admin`` and ``member``). This is arguable no worse than a deployment that is already defining the proposed roles. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Deployers should be made aware of the changes through release notes and possible logging messages. If they wish to ignore the new defaults proposed, they can continue to override the default using the same workflow they use today. Developer Impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: None Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. * Rethink how we test policy operations and extend the current testing framework to easily support test cases with various roles and outcomes. * Gradually parse each resource group and determine which role is appropriate for their management. * Write developer documentation for testing new APIs under each role and what the expected outcome should be. * Write deployer and installation documentation that emphasises the effect of consistent roles across deployment services. Dependencies ============ * We will need a specification proposed to oslo.policy that allows us to deprecate or notify changes to default policy rules/roles. Documentation Impact ==================== The documentation team might need some help providing documentation that clearly states what each role does and why it exists (from and OpenStack-wide perspective). References ========== None.

commit_message:
set paginated to False for list operations

For general purpose, consumers of the list operations are expecting only
the first page of the results, no matter whether limit or marker is set.
Thus using paginated=True in these operations hardly makes sense.

And the worse thing is that when paginated is set to True with limit
being set, the limit parameter will in fact limit the amount of entries
in each page, the generator will keep yielding objects with more than
one API calls made, and the total number of items being return from the
query is not limited as expected.

Change-Id: If1acda830439ae0b1d4b363b7a8e32e68397bcd3
Closes-Bug: #1716760

commit_message:
Fix wrong version of libssl for couchdbase

The couchbase guest image can't be built due to a wrong version
of libssl package.

The version 0.9.8 is no longer available.

https://packages.ubuntu.com/trusty/libssl-dev

Closes-Bug: #1746117
Change-Id: Iaf9c6aad2e154a1385860290bcdb4eefaaf36540
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/37/539037/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: apt-get --allow-unauthenticated install -qy libssl1.0.0

commit_message:
Add masakari and service-type instance-ha

The masakari project is an Official OpenStack project.

It has used the 'ha' service-type up until now, but that's a bit broad.
It was agreed that 'instance-ha' would be better. Add it to the registry.

The api-ref documentation is not currently published, but it does exist
in tree:

  http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/masakari/tree/api-ref/source

The jobs to publish it have been added:

  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/534878

but as the api-ref publication jobs use service-types-authority to
determine the correct place to publish to, the api-ref docs won't exist
until we land this. Once we do and once a publication job runs, they
should be found at the appropriate place.

Change-Id: Icdd0b09060ddd71b2313a90c1d62d84c31cdbb8d
